page.title: 12TEMPLE WOOD,KIRKBY UNDERWOOD
page.content: The whole of Temple Wood, stretching to some 226 acres falls within this area. The wood is managed by the Forestry Commission and is a mixture of deciduous and conifer plantation, mainly the former. The wood has a thinning cycle of 5 years with the main timber use that of pit prop production, second grade wood being shredded for use as chipboard or pulped for paper. Within the wood in addition to Beech and Birch are several young Oaks of about 40 years of age and the rarer species of Small-leaved Lime, Wild Service, Giant Fir, Corsican Pine and Aspen. Some of the rarer flowers to be found within the wood include Adders Tongue(Arum), Herb Paris(Lily family) and certain species of Orchid. .... cont.
